In mathematics, to 'solve an equation' is to find what values (numbers,
functions, sets, etc.) fulfill a condition stated in the form of an equation
(two expressions related by equality). These expressions contain one or more
'unknowns', which are free variables for which values are sought that cause the
condition to be fulfilled. To be precise, what is sought are often not
necessarily actual values, but, more in general, mathematical expressions. A
'solution' of the equation is an assignment of expressions to the unknowns that
satisfies the equation; in other words, expressions such that, when they are
substituted for the unknowns, the equation becomes an identity.

For example, the equation is solved for the unknown x by the solution , since
substituting for x in the equation results in , a true statement. It is also
possible to take the variable y to be the unknown, and then the equation is
solved by . Or x and y can both be treated as unknowns, and then there are many
solutions to the equation, some of which are â that is, and â and , and, in
general, for all possible values of a.

Depending on the problem, the task may be to find one solution â any solution
will do â or all solutions. The set of all solutions is called the solution set.
It is also possible that the task is to find a solution, among possibly many,
that is best in some respect. Problems of that nature are called optimization
problems; solving an optimization problem is generally not referred to as
"equation solving".

A wording such as "an equation 'in' x and y", or "solve 'for' x and y", implies
that the unknowns are as indicated: in these cases x and y.
